dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, welcome back to the pod, everyone! So, Host_B, I was just reading this article about, uh, security tokens. Remember all the hype around them like a year or two ago?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, welcome back to the pod, everyone! So, Host B, I was just reading this article about, uh, security tokens. Remember all the hype around them like a year or two ago?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, absolutely! I mean, the idea made total sense, right? Like, turning traditional stuff, real estate, company stock, into these digital assets to make them, um, more portable, more liquid. Everyone was calling it the next big thing in crypto.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, absolutely! I mean, the idea made total sense, right? Like, turning traditional stuff, real estate, company stock, into these digital assets to make them, um, more portable, more liquid. Everyone was calling it the next big thing in crypto.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The underlying idea made sense: creating digital versions of paper documents like private real estate investments and company stock would make them more portable and liquid, driving up demand. Many called it the next mega-trend in crypto.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And then... crickets. [chuckles] It feels like, fast forward to now, and progress has just totally stalled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And then... crickets. It feels like, fast forward to now, and progress has just totally stalled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really has. I mean, the article mentioned over a hundred security tokens have been created, but they’re just… not liquid. Like, zero volume, practically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really has. I mean, the article mentioned over a hundred security tokens have been created, but they're just... not liquid. Like, zero volume, practically.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More than 100 security tokens have been created, according to Polymath, a startup that helps companies mint coins. But theyre not liquid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? In the U.S., I think it said there are only two exchanges, and one of them, Openfinance, trades like, four assets with less than a million dollars a day? That’s, uh, tiny.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? In the U.S., I think it said there are only two exchanges, and one of them, Openfinance, trades like, four assets with less than a million dollars a day? That's, uh, tiny.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the U.S., just two exchanges exist where these assets trade, and volume is tiny. Openfinance trades only four assets with daily transactions of less than $1 million a day, we estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, why? What happened? The article pointed to, um, regulation as a huge barrier, didn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, why? What happened? The article pointed to, um, regulation as a huge barrier, didn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many of the barriers to adoption are regulation-related.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. For a company to even build a trading venue here, they have to register as a broker-dealer with the SEC, and then get an ATS license, which is like, a super long and costly process. One CEO even said the SEC is dragging its feet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. For a company to even build a trading venue here, they have to register as a broker-dealer with the S E C, and then get an A T S license, which is like, a super long and costly process. One C E O even said the S E C is dragging its feet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For U.S. companies to build a trading venue for security tokens, they must register as a broker-dealer with the SEC and get a license for either an exchange or an alternative trading system (ATS), which requires a long and costly process. One crypto CEO says the SEC is dragging its feet on evaluating and granting new ATS applications to digital asset companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And then there are those holding periods too, right? Like, after a new security is formed, it typically can’t change hands for a whole year. That just kills liquidity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there are those holding periods too, right? Like, after a new security is formed, it typically can't change hands for a whole year. That just kills liquidity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Holding periods are also a delaying factor: After a brand new security is formed and purchased by an initial buyer, it typically cant change hands for a year due to regulations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really does. And I think many people just completely underestimated the difficulty of generating actual investor demand for these things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really does. And I think many people just completely underestimated the difficulty of generating actual investor demand for these things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many people had underestimated the difficulty of generating investor demand for securities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Like, that quote from Dovey Wan, you know? "Yelling the word 'token' isn't a substitute for a good investment or distribution channels." Josh Stein from Harbor, uh, totally agreed with that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Like, that quote from Dovey Wan, you know? Yelling the word token isn't a substitute for a good investment or distribution channels. Josh Stein from Harbor, uh, totally agreed with that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Josh Stein, CEO of San Francisco security token platform Harbor, agrees. People have realized that yelling the word token is not a substitute for a good investment or distribution channels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Remember Harbor’s big $20 million offering that got canceled because the real estate firm couldn’t get favorable loan terms? It just, uh, shows how complex it is.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Remember Harbor's big twenty million dollar offering that got canceled because the real estate firm couldn't get favorable loan terms? It just, uh, shows how complex it is.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In April, a $20 million security token offering led by Harbor was canceled after the participating real estate firm, Convexity Properties, couldnt get favorable terms on the loan it was using to finance the deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But, I mean, the long-term benefits still sound compelling. Like, Olga Feldmeier mentioned the potential for a global IPO, where a U.S. investor could easily invest in a company in Mumbai.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, I mean, the long-term benefits still sound compelling. Like, Olga Feldmeier mentioned the potential for a global I P O, where a U.S. investor could easily invest in a company in Mumbai.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In theory, security tokens could allow for a global IPO, says Olga Feldmeier, founder and CEO of Swiss security token exchange Smart Valor. Ideally with these tokens, U.S. investors could just as easily invest in a public company based in Mumbai as they could a New York company, which is far from the case today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, in theory! But then you need *all* nations to agree on a common framework, which is, uh, a monumental task. Switzerland can do settlement on the blockchain, but the U.S. is still tied to the DTCC.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, in theory! But then you need all nations to agree on a common framework, which is, uh, a monumental task. Switzerland can do settlement on the blockchain, but the U.S. is still tied to the D T C C.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But all participating nations would need to agree on a common framework. For example, in Switzerland, securities settlement can already happen on the blockchain, Feldmeier says. In the U.S., its controlled by the DTCC, a New Jersey clearinghouse that handles 90 million transactions daily.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, faster settlement for banking transactions, that shared ledger idea, still feels really powerful. It just removes so many middlemen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, faster settlement for banking transactions, that shared ledger idea, still feels really powerful. It just removes so many middlemen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fred Schebesta, founder of Australian comparison site Finder and cofounder of crypto exchange HiveEx, says that faster settlement for banking transactions is the most important feature, since multiple parties can plug into the same shared ledger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does, it really does. But the short-term outlook seems pretty dim. One expert said we’d be in about the same place a year from now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, it really does. But the short-term outlook seems pretty dim. One expert said we'd be in about the same place a year from now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The short-term outlook seems dim. A year from now, well be in about the same place, said Philippe Bekhazi, CEO of crypto trading firm XBTO, at the Consensus conference last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Feldmeier thinks it'll take, what, five to ten years to build that cross-jurisdictional infrastructure? So, if adoption is reliant on regulators making moves, investors are going to be waiting a *long* time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Feldmeier thinks it'll take, what, five to ten years to build that cross-jurisdictional infrastructure? So, if adoption is reliant on regulators making moves, investors are going to be waiting a long time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Smart Valors Olga Feldmeier thinks it will take five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure necessary for security tokens to trade across nearly every country. One thing is for sure: if adoption is contingent on regulators making a move, investors will be waiting longer than theyd like.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, that much is definitely clear. It's a waiting game, it seems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, that much is definitely clear. It's a waiting game, it seems.
